body.p:
Dear Sir—I enclose you a list of the
subscribers I have been enabled to obtain for the
Advocate. While sorry it is so meagre, I cannot
but think that if the paper appears, you will get
more, and if every congregation in the U. S. and elsewhere
will do their share in proportion to one small cong.
I do not doubt but you will publish at once.
I regret the delay in forwarding you the list, sending
it as i do at the extreme limit of the time advertised
but the holydays, and after these, my absence twice
from the city, and then a severe catarrh which
kept me in the house a good week, all these did
their share in delaying. I would have answered
before this your last letter, but that I waited to send
the list, and now it is only necessary for me to refer to
one portion of it wherein you say my “cooperation” in
any shape will be esteemed, or acceptable—I have not
your letter before me, and don't recollect the exact
expressive, but if you mean literary cooperation

I am sorry to say that I cannot give it so readily as the
procuring of a few subscribers: First, there remains on “public
record” in the Occident a price (I might say prices for the
article on the election at Phila referring to the candidates makes
it appear that certain testimonials were given me by way of
favor, else why publish that so & so is a relative—the other
a friend—the other a co-laborateur &c—but I pass this) In
the piece to which I refer—your review of the Catechism
I am made to appear in no very enviable a light—and
as unsafe a writer as the “Israelite” editors—moreover
you accuse me in the same article of “doing you some wrong”
You may smile at my frivolous whims” but I take a leaf
out of your book, and have determined I am right, and
ought not to write for any paper conducted by you, until
you see fit to find opportunity in the same public manner
to imply the contrary of the interpretation I and all
others I include all those of your friends
whom I have had opportunity to see, (and they are many,)
especially during the last year. Again—and this is
difficulty the second in the way of literary cooperation
I am not situated now as I was when I was a
contributor to the Occident. I have now a family, and
my time therefore becomes more valuable—Having had
—and still having—fair offers of remuneration for literary
labor from other sources, I could not properly become
a contributor gratis to the Advocate, tho, I very readily become a

subscriber, & will otherwise do what I can for it. I tell you
candidly the reason why I did not accept a very fair
offer from another Jewish paper is that I am bound now
to employ my time for the best advantage of my family. If
however the first difficulty be removed, and the second also
to some extent—i.e. You think my pen worth anything
—not only for the Advocate, but for the Occident or what
not—then I can assure you I would sooner employ it for
an orthodox paper than another. I trust I have now
been explicit enough—I have desired to be so, as both your
time & mine is too short for a long correspondence on the
subject. Please think the matter over; for it depends
now entirely (I think) on you as to whether “bygones shall
be bygones” and we work together cheerfully advantageously
& understandingly—wiser for what is past. Should
you see difficulties insufferable on your side, and we do
not work together—then, after the above frank explanation
you must be neither surprised nor amazed if I chance
some future day to appear in another corner of the field
you have entered—working by myself or in company with
another. At present however this is not probable. Do not
suppose from what I have just written that I wish thereby
to influence your determination, for you will be greatly
mistaken; and next please do not think I look to profit
alone—for I could always more profitably employ myself in or
for publications not exclusively Jewish—Where there are
few laborers in Anglo-Jewish literature I prefer being

among them, the good natured are at liberty to say because
I stand less chance of being extinguished.

Miss Belisario is I believe disappointed at the
small circulation her book has in America. Can't you
do something for it? I think it a very deserving publication
—not because my fathers name is on the cover—for it was
the almost entirely malgrè lui—but Miss B. is a very
intimate friend of the family at home. I induced her first
to learn Hebrew—giving her myself a little gratuitous instruction
—and I have vanity enough to believe her when she says
that this gave her more especially able for religious readings & writings.
She ought to be encouraged; and your editorial gentleman not
too severe in your criticisms. (altho' mal-apropos I can't
help asking you whether you have seen a slashing article
on silly novels by Lady novelists in the ? for October—the writer has been
to a certaintly jilted by one of them) but to return a nos ?
As Miss B. shows such a positive preference (literary!)
for you over Marks, I hope you will be able to return
my friends penchante. I have not seen yet the second part of
her book. I hope to hear soon from you & remain
